locations/fraf.html.title: Fraf
locations/fraf.html.description:
Fraf is a small mining camp 200 miles inland of Stormrest on the continent of Amuth, the Northern Continent of the New World. It is not in the colonies Empire of Brateranth, rather it is in the Elven Nations.
It has no Imperial Administration control and no rule-of law. There are some large mines but mostly there are people panning the rivers and streams in the surrounds. All manner of people from all manner of places are in town.The towns leadership is the mostly corrupt owners of various businesses who have the money to buy muscle.
Having said this, the Empire of Brateranth absolutely claims the town and it collects taxes. Although they provide only basic security with a largely corrupt and incompetent Imperial Guard.
Dwarves have a mining venture and are allied with the Gnomes who have built a water powered Gold crushing and extraction mill.The reach of the empire is too wide and their resources too thin to control another whole continent away from their homeland although they are building a tower in the town and have posted Guardsmen, they struggle to maintin strong momentum.Key among the challenges is contending with the Elvish Tribe and there resistant to the taking of their land.

locations/stormrest.html.title: Stormrest
locations/stormrest.html.description:
Stormrest is no longer a simple provincial town, but the major coastal hub for the Old World Empire's trade and military projection into this territory. Its prosperity is visible in the massive stone docks and fortified walls, but this wealth is entirely built on imperial extraction. The city is divided into three distinct zones: the Imperial Citadel, the bustling Port District, and the impoverished, resentful Old Town.The atmosphere is heavy with resentment. Imperial soldiers patrol rigidly, and citizens often gather in tight groups, whispering about the harsh Trade Tariffs and the Governor's Autocratic Rule. Revolution is not yet open, but the embers are glowing. Location: Built atop the highest bluff, overlooking the entire city and harbor. It is highly fortified. The Governor's Palace: The seat of power, home to Governor Valerius(The Iron Fist). He is paranoid, rarely leaves the Citadel, and relies on Imperial Army to maintain order. He is the ultimate source of the high taxes and is fiercely anti-representation. The Tax Office: All official paperwork, licenses, and trade taxes are processed here. A PC needs a "Citizen Pass" (5gp, valid for 30 days) just to conduct business outside of the Port District.
The Merchant Guildhall: Where Merrick Bramblecart (and likely his contacts) does business. The Guild is currently split: wealthy merchants support the Empire for protection, while smaller traders (like Merrick) resent the exorbitant tariffs. The City Gate (Now the Imperial Checkpoint): Heavily guarded (4 well-equipped Imperial Soldiers at all times). The Trade Tax: Any goods leaving Stormrest toward Fraf are subject to a 25% tariff levied by the Empire. Contraband: Imperial law is strict. Possession of unlicenced magic items or powerful weapons is grounds for seizure and detainment (DC 14 Save or 1d6 days in Imperial Jail).
The "Unburdened Hand" Tavern: A notoriously dingy tavern in the slums that serves as the unofficial meeting spot for the burgeoning The Restless Hearth Faction (the revolutionaries). Propaganda: Pamphlets and posters discussing "Taxation Without Representation" are often slipped into pockets or left on tables here.
The Contact (Marius "The Cinder"): A charismatic, scarred man who recruits locals for the revolution. He sees adventurers as potential muscle and will attempt to sway the PCs by paying them 10gp for simple tasks like delivering messages or vandalizing Imperial property.

introduction-to-the-world.html.title: Introduction to the World
introduction-to-the-world.html.description:
Welcome to the continent of Amuth, a land of rugged frontiers, imperial expansion, and ancient, shifting powers. As common citizens of the Empire or travelers seeking fortune, the following is what you would know as you walk the streets of a major hub like Stormrest or prepare for the long road west.The Empire of Brateranth is the dominant political force in the known world, though its grip loosens the further you travel from the coast.
The Sanction on Magic: All arcane magic—spells cast by Magic-Users—is strictly illegal unless registered and sanctioned by the Imperial Administration. Magi of the Empire: These robed enforcers, serve as the Empire's "arcane police," hunting down "wild" or unregistered casters. Taxation and Order: Imperial soldiers, led by officers, are a constant presence, focused on collecting trade tariffs and maintaining a rigid, often brutal, version of "order". Unlike arcane magic, the power of the Elemental Gods is a respected and legal part of daily life.
Clerical Administration: Clerics are the sanctioned spiritual leaders of the Empire. They are responsible for maintaining the elemental ley lines—invisible conduits of divine energy that keep the world in balance. Divine vs. Arcane: To a general citizen, the distinction is clear: Clerics are keepers of the natural order, while "wild" mages are dangerous threats to it. Most travelers find themselves in the port city of Stormrest, the gateway to the "New World".
The Gold Rush: Rumors are flying about a massive gold strike in the northern mining camp of Fraf. It is a place of "mud and raw lumber," attracting anyone looking to get rich—and the complications that come with them. Wilderness Dangers: Beyond the boundary stones of the core provinces, the "Peace of the Empire" thins. The roads are plagued by bandits, oversized vermin, and the occasional elven hunting party. The Elven Nations: The land to the west of Stormrest technically belongs to the Elven Nations. While the Empire claims the territory and collects taxes, the local Elves often view travelers as trespassers on their ancestral lands.

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
